docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., the health care and insurance provider, promoted Richard L. Huber to president and chief executive yesterday, ending weeks of uncertainty after the resignation of Joseph T. Sebastianelli. In choosing Mr. Huber, 60, who had been vice chairman of strategy and finance, Aetna opted for a manager with knowledge of finance, not one with a career in health care. Aetna stock fell $2.4375, to $112.625, on the New York Stock Exchange amid concern the company would be better off if its top executive had a background in health care, said Cathy Seifert, an analyst at Standard & Poor's Corporation. The Hartford-based company sold its property and casualty insurance business last year and paid $8.9 billion for U.S. Healthcare.

headline.main: AETNA NAMES PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc names Richard L Huber as president and chief executive, ending weeks of uncertainty after resignation of Joseph T Sebastianelli (S)
docs.snippet: Aetna Inc., the health care and insurance provider, promoted Richard L. Huber to president and chief executive yesterday, ending weeks of uncertainty after the resignation of Joseph T. Sebastianelli. In choosing Mr. Huber, 60, who had been vice...

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans bowed to President Clinton's demands today and tentatively agreed to restore disability benefits to more than half a million legal immigrants, as budget negotiators broke a weeklong impasse and began making progress on several bitterly contested issues. The Republicans also agreed to continue Medicaid coverage for tens of thousands of children who would otherwise lose it, along with their disability benefits, under the welfare law that the President signed last August.

headline.main: TALKS ON BUDGET YIELD AN ACCORD ON DISABILITY AID

docs.abstract: Congressional Republicans, breaking impasse in budget talks, tenatively agree to Pres Clinton's demands to restore disability benefits to legal immigrants and continue Medicaid coverage for disabled children who lost Supplemental Security Income under 1996 welfare law; negotiators pare their ranks to most senior participants and reportedly work to resolve specific tax and spending issues; reportedly are making faster progress on spending issues; Clinton expresses optimism on accord (M)
docs.snippet: Congressional Republicans bowed to President Clinton's demands today and tentatively agreed to restore disability benefits to more than half a million legal immigrants, as budget negotiators broke a weeklong impasse and began making progress on...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration edged toward serious give-and-take with the Republican leadership today over how to cut taxes, with the outlines of a compromise apparent to both sides but neither willing to make the first big concession. White House officials shuttled from meeting to meeting on Capitol Hill throughout the day and into the evening, sounding out the priorities of their fellow Democrats and providing Republicans with blunt assessments of what it would take to produce a tax bill that President Clinton would be willing to sign.

headline.main: In Tax Talks, Officials Play Game of Cat And Mouse

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration edges toward serious give-and-take with Republican leadership over how to cut taxes; outlines of compromise seem apparent to both sides, but neither is willing to make first big concession; deep divisions remain as Administration demands Republicans modify capital gains tax cut, expand per-child credits to more low-income families and increase tax breaks for college costs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In courting acquisition candidates, executives of Tenet Healthcare, the nation's second-largest hospital chain, have taken advantage of what they call the ''ABC phenomenon'' -- anything but Columbia. For hospitals rattled by Columbia/HCA's aggressive tactics, Tenet portrays itself as a rescuer and a companion, even letting acquired hospitals keep their own names.
docs.abstract: Executives at Tenet Healthcare, in courting acquisition candidates, have taken advantage of what they call the 'ABC phenomenon'--anything but Columbia; for hospitals rattled by Columbia/HCA's aggressive tactics, Tenet portrays itself as a rescuer and a companion, even letting acquired hospitals keep their own names; Tenet could be friendliest available partner for Columbia/HCA; Columbia, more than twice the size of Tenet, is facing Federal investigations of its most basic practices (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Richard L. Scott, a deal maker who built the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the country's biggest for-profit hospital chain, appears close to resigning as chairman and chief executive. The Columbia/HCA board was meeting last night in Nashville, where the company is based, to decide strategy on dealing with an array of Government fraud investigations, which have depressed Columbia share prices, and a takeover discussion with the Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the second-largest investor-owned hospital chain.

headline.main: Chief Seems About to Quit At Columbia

docs.abstract: Richard L Scott, deal maker who built Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, country's biggest for-profit hospital chain, appears close to resigning as chairman and chief executive; Columbia/HCA board meets to decide strategy of dealing with array of Government fraud investigations, which have depressed Columbia share prices, and takeover discussion with Tenet Healthcare Corp, second-largest investor-owned hospital chain; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican leaders of the House and the Senate agreed today on a $16 billion plan to provide health care for uninsured children, the biggest investment in children's health since Medicaid was created in 1965. But President Clinton said the proposal was unacceptable because it did not guarantee adequate health benefits for children. Mr. Clinton said the Republican proposal would give states too much leeway in designing their programs, and he insisted that Congress guarantee a more comprehensive package of specific benefits.

headline.main: G.O.P. LEADERSHIP AGREES ON A PLAN TO COVER CHILDREN

docs.abstract: Republican leaders of House and Senate agree on plan to provide health care for uninsure children, but Pres Clinton says proposal does not guarantee adequate benefits and gives states too much leeway in designing programs; Republican plan would give states $16 billion over five years to finance health care and health insurance for children; Clinton urges Congress to provide $24 billion, with extra money coming from tobacco taxes proposed by Senate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A study has found that healthy newborns who remain hospitalized for more than a day generally fare better than those who go home a few hours after birth. Researchers studied 310,000 births in Washington state from 1991 through 1994. Newborns discharged within 30 hours were 28 percent more likely to need rehospitalization within a week than newborns who stayed hospitalized 30 hours or more.
docs.abstract: Healthy newborns who remain hospitalized for more than a day are found to fare better in general than those who go home few hours after birth (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a push to achieve long-range savings in the Medicare program, President Clinton today vowed to ''defend the vote of any member of Congress, Democrat or Republican,'' who supported raising premiums for the affluent elderly. Mr. Clinton spoke a day after Congressional budget negotiators reached an impasse in talks to rein in the cost of the Federal health insurance program for the elderly. House Republicans said they feared that adopting the proposed savings would make them vulnerable to Democratic attacks in next year's Congressional campaigns.

headline.main: President Offers to Back Congress in Effort to Reduce Costs of Medicare Program

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, seeking long-range savings in Medicare program, vows to defend vote of any member of Congress, Democrat or Republican, who backs raising premiums for affluent elderly; responds to fears of House Republicans that adopting proposed savings will make them vulnerable to Democratic attacks (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Inflation is dead, right? After all, despite more than six years of uninterrupted economic growth and with unemployment now near the levels last enjoyed in the 1960's and early 1970's, consumer prices have risen at a mere 1.4 percent rate so far this year. And the cost of manufactured goods is actually falling. But don't count out the old nemesis just yet. While hardly anybody is predicting apocalypse soon, there is reason to believe that unemployment is already below the rate consistent with price stability.
docs.abstract: Peter Passell analysis finds that inflation may be creeping quietly back into nation's economy, despite widespread economic optimism that has helped power both stock market and Pres Clinton's popularity to new highs; cites likely end to set of conditions that have helped hold infation in check, such as low price of oil and strong dollar, which has kept imports inexpensive; unemployment, at approximately 5 percent, is already below rate consistent with price stability (M)
